poem:
**Golden Gate**

Venus strides through  
the golden gate,  
past Taurus' watchful eye.  
Starry clusters part,  
Hyades and Pleiades,  
braid the night in silken skeins.  
An ecliptic dance,  
celestial waltz,  
the sky's whispered secret  
held in luminous orbit—  
a cosmic passage,  
timeless, unseen,  
yet mapped in silver light.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Starwatch: Venus will pass through the ‘golden gate’ of two star clusters This week, Venus will pass through the so-called Golden Gate of the Ecliptic. Although the name has risen to prominence with science popularisers in recent decades, its exact origin is unknown. It references two star clusters in the constellation Taurus, the Bull. The Hydes and the Pleiades lie on either side of the ecliptic, which is the plane of the solar system. As". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
